questions.question: How does homework usually go in your home?

options.label: Daily battle – often ends in tears
Challenging but we get through it

insight.helped_us: We learned that homework after a full school day is asking our child's depleted executive function to do the impossible. Setting a strict time limit (not task completion) was game-changing.
insight.science: After 6-7 hours of masking and compensating at school, the 'cognitive battery' is empty. Forcing homework leads to shutdown or meltdown, not learning.
insight.quick_tip: Set a timer for 15-20 minutes. When it rings, homework ends – regardless of completion. Communicate this with the teacher.

questions.question: Does your child have autism, ADHD, or both?

insight.helped_us: Understanding that 30-80% of autistic children also have ADHD helped us stop treating these as separate issues. They interact in complex ways.
insight.science: Co-occurring autism and ADHD create unique challenges. Autism needs predictability; ADHD needs stimulation. Finding the sweet spot requires understanding both.
insight.quick_tip: If both are present, prioritize strategies that address both: visual timers (autism) that create urgency (ADHD) work beautifully.

questions.question: How are your morning and evening routines?

insight.helped_us: A visual morning plan with pictures gave our child enormous security. No more constant questions about 'What's next?' – they can see the sequence.
insight.science: Predictable routines reduce cortisol levels in autistic children by up to 40%. Predictability isn't a luxury – it's a neurobiological need.
insight.quick_tip: Start with 3-5 fixed steps: Wake up → Get dressed → Breakfast. Visualize them with photos or symbols.

questions.question: How often do you experience meltdowns or severe overwhelm?

insight.helped_us: We learned to recognize the signs earlier: higher voice pitch, starting to fidget, glazed eyes. Then our child needs immediate retreat – no negotiation.
insight.science: Meltdowns aren't tantrums – they're neurological overload reactions. The nervous system switches to survival mode. Early recognition prevents escalation.
insight.quick_tip: Watch for 3 early warning signs: body language, voice tone, withdrawal impulse. Then: reduce stimuli, don't discuss.

questions.question: Can your child express their needs and feelings well?

options.label: Very difficult – often only through behavior

insight.helped_us: Visual tools were the breakthrough. Our child can now point to a scale instead of having to explain: 'My battery is empty' or 'Too many stimuli.'
insight.science: Alexithymia (difficulty recognizing/naming emotions) affects about 50% of autistic people. Visual communication bypasses the language barrier.
insight.quick_tip: Use traffic light systems: Green = OK, Yellow = need break, Red = overwhelmed. Simple but effective.

insight.helped_us: The support aide was crucial. But clear communication with the teacher really helped. We developed an emergency plan together.
insight.science: Studies show: Clear structures, consistent support person, and retreat options are the three most important factors for successful inclusion.
insight.quick_tip: Schedule a monthly 15-minute meeting with the teacher. Regular, brief, solution-focused.

questions.question: How do you handle transitions and changes?

options.label: Very difficult – every change is a battle

insight.helped_us: Visual countdown + announcement 10-5-1 minutes before. Our child can mentally prepare. Without warning: chaos. With warning: manageable.
insight.science: Autistic brains have difficulty with 'set-shifting' (task switching). Warning time activates prefrontal control systems and reduces stress.
insight.quick_tip: Use timers with visual countdown. Don't say 'Soon,' say 'In 5 minutes.' Stay concrete.

questions.question: Does your child struggle with focus and attention?

options.label: Yes, severe – can't start tasks, constant distraction

insight.helped_us: We stopped saying 'just focus!' – ADHD brains literally can't regulate attention that way. External structure (timers, body doubling, breaks) replaced internal willpower.
insight.science: ADHD isn't a focus problem – it's an attention regulation problem. The brain can hyperfocus on engaging tasks but struggles with 'boring' necessary ones.
insight.quick_tip: Use Pomodoro technique: 15-minute work sprints with 5-minute breaks. External structure compensates for internal regulation difficulties.

questions.question: How challenging are public situations (shopping, restaurants, etc.)?

options.label: We avoid it mostly – too stressful
Only short trips or with preparation

insight.helped_us: Noise-cancelling headphones are our lifesaver. Plus: we shop at less busy times. Saturday at 11 AM? Never again.
insight.science: Sensory filtering works differently in autism. All sensory input arrives unfiltered – a supermarket is pure sensory overload.
insight.quick_tip: Plan sensorially friendly times: early morning or late evening. Bring headphones. Announce duration.

questions.question: What's your biggest wish right now?

options.label: More peace in daily life – fewer conflicts

insight.helped_us: We understood: there's no perfect solution. But there are many small helps that together make a huge difference.
insight.science: Small, consistent changes have greater long-term impact than large, one-time interventions. Sustainability beats intensity.
insight.quick_tip: Choose ONE thing you want to improve in the next 2 weeks. Not ten. One.

questions.question: How does your child handle medical appointments (doctor, dentist)?

options.label: Extremely stressful – often meltdowns or complete refusal
Difficult but doable with lots of preparation

insight.helped_us: We started reading social stories about the dentist 3 days before. Our child knew exactly what would happen – no surprises, much less fear. We also brought noise-cancelling headphones.
insight.science: Medical anxiety in autistic children isn't irrational – it's sensory (bright lights, strange sounds, being touched) plus uncertainty. Predictability through preparation reduces anxiety by up to 60%.
insight.quick_tip: Call ahead: ask if you can visit when it's quiet, if they can dim lights, if you can bring comfort objects. Most offices accommodate when you explain.

questions.question: Are there big life changes coming up or ongoing?

options.label: Yes – moving, new sibling, school change, or similar
Some changes – learning new skills, friend sleepovers, etc.
Life is pretty stable right now

insight.helped_us: When our second child was born, we prepared our autistic son for 8 weeks with books, pictures, and conversations. He still struggled, but way less than if it had been a surprise. Preparation = everything.
insight.science: Major life transitions activate the stress response system. For autistic children, this can mean weeks of dysregulation. Early, repeated preparation allows the brain to build neural pathways for the new reality.
insight.quick_tip: For big changes: start preparing 4-8 weeks early. Use pictures, social stories, and repeated conversations. Make the unknown known.
